data.title: Barcelona 2
data.text:
The family of the Counts of Barcelona

Part 2

Ct Ramon Berenguer IV of Barcelona, etc (See Part 1) and his wife Queen Petronilla of Aragón had issue: [Note: the crowns of the Kingdom of Aragón and the County of Barcelona (along with the rest of Catalonia) were henceforth united, and the senior member was known by the grander title of King of Aragón, but Catalonia always remained semi-independent of Aragón. The King was always known as Count of Barcelona in Catalonia; The Catalans supplied most of the wealth of the kingdom, and were mostly responsible for the kingdom's expansion throughout the Mediterranean.]

1a) Pedro, b.Barcelona 4 Apr 1152, d.young at Huesca

2a) Ramón, who became King Alfonso II of Aragón, Ct of Barcelona, Girona, Osona, Besalu, Cerdagne and Roussillon, and, later, Ct of Provence (Huesca 1/25 Mar 1157-Perpignan 25 Apr 1195); m.Zaragoza 18 Jan 1174 Sancha (1155/7-Sijena 9 Nov 1208) dau.of King Alfonso VII of Castile; he may have m.1st Mafalda of Portugal, who died 1173/4

1b) King Pedro II "el Catolico" of Aragón etc (1174/6-k.a.Moret 4 Sep 1213); m.Montpellier 15 Jun 1204 Marie, Dame de Montpellier, whereby Aragón acquired this strategically important part of southern France

1c) Sancha (1205-1206)

2c) Jaime I "el Conquistador", King of Aragón, etc, led crusades against the Moors and was able to add the titles of King of Valencia and Mallorca to the throne (Montpellier 1 Feb 1207-Valencia 27 Jul 1276); m.1st Agreda 6 Feb 1221 (annulled 1229) Leonor, dau.of King Alfonso VIII of Castile; m.2nd Barcelona 8 Sep 1235 Yolande=Violante (d.Huesca 12 Oct 1251) dau.of King Andrew II of Hungary; m.3rd, secretly, Teresa, dau.of Juan de Vidaure
